> 
> In general, I'm in favor of that simplification. I don't
> see any compelling need to specify:
>     assertEquals(x,y)
> 
> rather than
>     verify(x == y)
> 
> But if you want to compare strings in SuiteRunner,
> you'll need to say:
>     verify(x.equals(y))
> 

Neither verify(x == y) nor verify(x.equals(y)) do the same thing as 
assertEquals(x, y).  The method verify(x == y) is the same as 
assertSame(x, y). For integers, etc. this is the same as 
assertEquals, true (although note that for floats and doubles, 
assertEquals has a third argument).  For Strings and such, however, 
assertEquals(x, y) handles the case when x (or y) is null, which does 
not happen with verify(x.equals(y)).

I personally also like getting the default message, but that is more 
of a personal preference than a technical difference.

-Kathy Van Stone
